context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: In the present case, however, what Congress threatens if the state refuses to agree to its condition is not the denial of a gift or of a gratuity, but rather a sanction, exclusion of the State from otherwise permissible activity.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Even in cases involving conditions attached to federal funding, we have acknowledged that the financial inducement offered by Congress might be so coercive as to pass the point at which “pressure turns into compulsion”.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Where the constitutionally guaranteed protection of the States' sovereign immunity is involved, the point of coercion is automatically passed, and the voluntariness of waiver destroyed when what is attached to the refusal to waive is the exclusion of the State from otherwise lawful activity.

context.text: In today’s world virtually every nation, every nation is open to suit when it acts, not like a government, but like a private business.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: For the Court today to overrule Parden and to hold that Congress doesn’t have the power to require States to do the same thing creates a serious practical, as well as a legal anomaly.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: I have the opinion of the Court to announce in No. 98-531, Florida Prepaid versus College Savings.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: In 1992, Congress amended the patent laws and expressly abrogated the immunity of the States' from claims of patent infringement.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: The respondent College Savings, which Justice Scalia described in his announcement, then sued the State of Florida for patent infringement, and the State of Florida argued that Congress exceeded its power in abrogating the State's immunity.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: The United States intervened to defend the constitutionality of the law.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: The Court of Appeals held that Congress had validly abrogated the State sovereign immunity from the infringement suits pursuant to its authority under Section 5 of the Fourteenth Amendment, and we granted certiorari and we now reverse.

Florida Prepaid Post-Secondary Education.speaker: Justice Rehnquist
Florida Prepaid Post-Secondary Education.case_name: Florida Prepaid Post-Secondary Education Expense Board v. College Savings Bank
Florida Prepaid Post-Secondary Education.title: OPINION ANNOUNCEMENT - JUNE 23, 1999

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Despite this lack of support, Congress enacted a remedial scheme that expose States to expensive liability for infringement and did nothing to tailor this scheme to reach at any conduct that might have violated the Fourteenth Amendment.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: The statutes apparent and more basic aims were to provide a uniform remedy for patent infringement and place the States on the same footing as private parties under that regime.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: These are proper Article I concerns, but not Fourteenth Amendment’s concerns, and just as Seminole tribe precludes Congress from enacting such legislation under Article I, the City of Boerne does the same under the Fourteenth Amendment in this case.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Justice Stevens has filed a dissenting opinion in which Justices Souter, Ginsburg and Breyer join.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Aticle I of the Constitution provides that Congress shall have power to promote the progress of science and useful arts by securing for limited times to authors and inventors the exclusive right to their respective writings and discoveries.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Pursuant to that expressed allegation of power, Congress has authorized the issuance of patents and litigation to protect patents and patentees that may only be brought in a Federal Court.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: In 1992, Congress clarified that jurisdictional grant by expressly authorizing patent infringement actions against States and State instrumentalities.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Given the fact that all 50 states are active participants in the patent system, Florida alone has obtained over 200 patents since the 1992 Act was passed.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: It is not only incongruous but potentially harmful to the uniform administration of this branch of federal law to conclude that that the States might simultaneously enjoy the benefits of that system and relay on the defense of sovereign immunity when charged with lawful patent infringement.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: If Congress does not have the power to provide a remedy for the patentee in a case like this, and if it cannot compel State Courts to entertain suits of this kind, as the court held in the case that Justice Kennedy announced, “There is a gapping hole in the law of patents, that I am quite sure the framers of the Constitution did not envision.”

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: That gapping hole is the product of this Court’s decision three years ago in the Seminole Tribe case.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Prior to that decision this Court had never held that Congress power to compel states to comply with federal law was limited by the doctrine of sovereign immunity, it had of course repeatedly told Congress that statutes limiting state authority must contain a clear statement that Congress intended them to apply to the States.

context.speaker: Carolyn M. Snurkowski
context.text: --I think there is probably some truth to the fact that time could pass along, but it doesn't mean that the probable cause in any way deteriorates.

context.speaker: Carolyn M. Snurkowski

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: The labor relations between federal agency and federal employee union are governed and administered by a special statute called the Federal Service Labor Management Relations Statute and a special agency that is called the Federal Labor Relations Authority, it is a little bit like the private sectors National Labor Relations Act in the NLRB.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Now, this case focuses upon a statutory requirement in that statute that I just mentioned, which says that federal agencies and unions "they must meet and negotiate in good faith for the purposes of arriving at a collective bargaining agreement".

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: That being so, we conclude that Congress intended the relevant administrative agency, namely the Federal Labor Relations Authority; the Congress intended that agency to decide whether, when, how, or what sort of midterm bargaining should take place.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: This case concerns Title II of the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990, a measure I will abbreviate as the ADA.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Title II of the ADA prohibits public entities from discriminating against persons with disabilities by reason of their disabilities.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: If for example, the State were to demonstrate that it had a comprehensive effectively working plan for placing qualified persons with mental disabilities in less restrictive settings, and the waiting list that moved at a reasonable pace not controlled by the State's endeavors to keep its institutions fully populated, the reasonable modifications requirement would be met.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: In sum, we conclude that Title II of the ADA requires States to provide community based treatment for persons with mental disabilities, when the State's treatment professionals have determined that such placement is appropriate, when the affected persons do not oppose such treatment, and when the placement can be reasonably accommodated taking into account the resources available to the State and the needs of others with mental disabilities.

context.text: Our opinion emphasizes that nothing in the ADA or its implementing regulations condones the termination of institutional treatment for persons unable to handle or benefit from community based care, nor is there any federal requirement that community based treatment be imposed on patients who do not desire it.
